a.title: Chief Communications, Strategy and Engagement Officer

div.a: Chief Communications, Strategy and Engagement Officer

nav.div: Rio Rancho Public Schools » Departments » Administration » Chief Communications, Strategy and Engagement Officer » Parent and Community Resources

img.title: Empty classroom with desks
img.style: width: 273px; height: 189px; float: left; left: 284px; margin-right: 10px;

span.style: letter-spacing: 0.3px; font-family: latobold; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(40, 40, 40);

span.span: Have you changed your phone number and/or email address since the beginning of the school year? Did you update your contact information with the registrar at your school's front office?

span.style: letter-spacing: 0.3px; font-family: Tahoma; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(40, 40, 40);

span.span: If not, please fill out our change of information form to receive updates from the district and your student's school(s):

br.style: color: rgb(40, 40, 40); font-family: Tahoma; font-size: 16px; letter-spacing: 0.3px;
color: rgb(40, 40, 40); font-family: Tahoma; font-size: 16px; letter-spacing: 0.3px;

span.style: text-decoration-line: none; letter-spacing: 0.3px; font-family: Tahoma; font-size: 16px; color: rgb(5, 16, 245);

a.title: Link to Change of Information Form
a.style: color: rgb(6, 1, 93); text-decoration-line: none; font-family: Tahoma; font-size: 16px; letter-spacing: 0.3px;

br.br: As part of the state's efforts to contain the COVID-19 virus, public K-12 schools throughout New Mexico have been ordered to close for the remainder of the 2019-20 school year. Students are required to learn at home to complete academic requirements: you may view these requirements and other learn-at-home resources here.

img.span: Please visit the tabs below to learn about meal sites, community resources, and more. We will add additional information to this page as it becomes available.

a.title: NM PED FAQ on extended school closures
a.strong: NM Public Education Department: FAQ on Extended School Closure

span.br: This provides some of the guidance we have received from the state regarding school closures. We will be sharing information with parents on specific plans and requirements for RRPS during the week of March 29-April 3.

br.span:
RESOURCE HOTLINE: Those who need to be connected to resources (food, baby formula, medical care, behavioral health services, etc.) may call the Rio Rancho Public Schools District Office hotline: (505) 896-0667 (Monday through Thursday, 9 a.m.-3 p.m.) Our team will do what we can to connect you to resources and/or put out a call for assistance for you on our social media and with our partners. We understand that these can be stressful times and we would like to do what we can to assist and relieve stress by providing resources or connecting parents and staff to resources should they need them.
Looking for ways to help? Visit this resource page from the New Mexico Department of Health.

a.title: NM PED FAQ on extended school closures

img.alt: Update on meal pickup: kids need not be present
img.title: Update on meal pickup: kids need not be present
img.style: width: 268px; height: 322px; float: right; margin-left: 10px; left: 280px;

div.span: The State of New Mexico has provided hotline numbers to answer New Mexicans' questions:

li.span: All other questions (businesses, schools, unemployment, child care, etc.): 1-833-551-0518
What can I do while the stay-at-home order is in place? The state has provided answers to stay-at-home frequently-asked questions here!

p.strong: For questions relating to Rio Rancho schools specifically
p.span: , please call (505) 896-0667 any time between 9 AM and 3 PM Monday-Thursday.

div.script:
$(document).ready(function () {
        var logConsole = function (str) {
            console.log(str);
        };
        if ($('#tabPortlet_510630 .divTabEdit').val() == "True") {
            var isModern = ('True');
            if(isModern.toLowerCase() == "true")
            {
                var tabObj = $('#tabPortlet_510630 ');
                var tabM = $('#ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs').attr('portlet') == 'tab';

                function activate() {
                    $(tabObj).scrollingTabs({                 
                        tabs: [{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs_0","title":"Food/Meals","content":"\n
RRPS SCHOOLS STUDENT MEAL ACCESS: Updated 4/6/20
\n
\nNote: Meal pickup will not be available on Friday, 4/10 (a school holiday).  Parents may pick up meals for both Thursday and Friday on Thursday, 4/9.
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\nDuring the mandatory school closure, grab-n-go breakfast and lunches will be made available to children up to the age of 18 at the following locations:\n\n    
Rio Rancho Middle School (11:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m.)\n    
Ernest Stapleton Elementary School (11 a.m. to 12 p.m.)\n    
Martin Luther King Jr. Elementary School (11 a.m. to 12 p.m.)\n    
Puesta del Sol Elementary School (11 a.m. to 12 p.m.)\n    
Colinas del Norte Elementary School (11:30 to 12:30 p.m.)\n    
Sandia Vista Elementary School (11 a.m. to 12 p.m.)\n    
Lincoln Middle School (11:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m.)\n    
Cleveland High School (12:30 PM to 1:30 PM)\n\n
Important change:  As of 4/6/20, students no longer need to accompany the adult/licensed driver in the vehicle in order to pick up meals.  
\n
\nIf you go to a RRPS meal site Monday through Friday during scheduled meal times and they have run out of bagged breakfasts or lunches, call (505) 938-0386 or go to our Cleveland High School meal site which intentionally has a later distribution time of 12:30 p.m. to 1:30 p.m.
\n
\nIf you need to have meals delivered, please fill out our Meal Delivery Request Form: \n
Meal Delivery Request Form
\n\n
\n

\nPlease note that some meals contain foods which require reheating to 140 degrees; please follow the manufacturer's instructions on the package.  If you use a microwave, remember to remove foil wraps prior to putting the food into the microwave.   
\n\n
\n
\nPRESBYTERIAN HEALTH SERVICES FREE MEALS FOR CHILDREN:
\n
\nPresbyterian Health Services facilities, including Rust Presbyterian Hospital in Rio Rancho, offer free meals to children ages 0-18 visiting the hospital:
\n
\n\n
Presbyterian Rust Medical Center
\nM-F: breakfast 6:30 a.m.- 10 a.m.
\nM-F: lunch 11 a.m. - 2 p.m.
\n
\nPresbyterian Hospital
\nM-F: meal 11 a.m. - 1 p.m
\n
\nPresbyterian Kaseman Hospital
\nM-F: meal 11 a.m. - 4 p.m.\n

\nMeals are also available at other centers in New Mexico including Presbyterian Santa Fe Medical Center, Plains Regional Medical Center, Socorro General Hospital, and Lincoln County Medical Center.
\n\n

\nClick here for more information.
\n
\nSTOREHOUSE WEST:
\n
\nBeginning this Wednesday, Storehouse West will offer drive-up service to its client families needing to pick up foodstuffs.  Storehouse West is open during its regular operating hours on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday (9 AM - 1:30 PM on Monday and Friday, and 12 PM to 4:30 PM on Wednesdays).  For more information, click here to visit Storehouse West's website.  
\n
\n
\n","active":true,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs_1","title":"Child Care","content":"
NEW MEXICO CHILDREN, YOUTH, AND FAMILIES DEPARTMENT (CYFD)
\n
\nThe state has a Child Care Resource and Referral line to help families find child care (1-800-691-9067; www.NewMexicoKids.Org). Families can also contact their CYFD eligibility specialist via phone or email to let them know they now need full-time care; their team across the state will amend the contracts. In addition, all parents receiving child care assistance will have their copays waived during the public health emergency. 
\n
\nIn addition, CYFD is expanding assistance to include first responders and health care providers who need child care assistance and is temporarily registering family, friend and neighbor (FFN) providers who may be eligible to receive child care assistance funding.  For further information about all of CYFD's child care initiatives, visit their child care web portal.  \n\n    
Child Care Assistance Application (PDF)\n    
Solicitud de Asistencia de Cuidado Infantil (PDF)\n\n

\n","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs_2","title":"Community Resources","content":"Many government, civic, and business organizations throughout Rio Rancho and the Albuquerque Metro are stepping up to help people and families.  Here is a list of some of those services (we'll keep adding to it as information becomes available:
\n
\nCommunity Resources:
\n
\n• Rio Rancho Regional Chamber Covid-19 Toolkit:  Includes a variety of community resources for seniors, small business, utilities, and much more!
\n
\nMental Health Services:
\n
\n• Sandoval Regional Medical Center (in Rio Rancho): Behavioral Health Clinic
\n• New Mexico Crisis and Access Line: NM Connect Mobile App
\n• NM Crisis Line: Mental Health and the Coronavirus Pandemic 
\n• CDC:  Managing Anxiety and Stress: Mental Health and Coping
\n
\nInternet Services:
\nSparklight is making special, low-cost provisions to help families access the internet during the COVID-19 pandemic.  These include a low-cost internet plan as well as access to a free hotspot in their parking lot at 7501 Nita PL. (on Enchanted Hills Blvd.):  
\n
\n• Press release (.pdf): Sparklight wireless hotspot and internet access
\n• Press release (.pdf): Low-cost internet service
\n
\nNewMexicoKids.Org:
\n
\n• The NewMexicoKids.org/Parents and Families site includes hotline numbers and websites for crisis resources, poison control, and more!
\n
\n• PullTogether.Org is a state website includes lots of great information for families on everything from educational activities to child care and more.  Some resources (such as libraries, museums, etc) may not be in operation during the coronavirus closures, but much of the information still applies.  
\n
\n","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs_3","title":"Things to Do","content":"As part of the State of Emergency, the Governor has stated that families should avoid going to public places where large numbers of people might gather.  These include, for example, going to parks to play, visiting the mall, going to movies, museums, and so on.   
\n
\nSo what to do to keep the kids occupied while schools are closed (besides play video games or watch TV)?  This article from Forbes.com has some great ones!
\n
\nHere are some ideas:
\n\n    
Take advantage of online educational resources (See our online learning tab)\n    
Read a favorite book\n    
Write a story\n    
Play board and card games\n    
Draw, paint, and create \n    
Play (or learn to play) music\n    
Go walking or hiking\n    
Play outdoors in a socially-distanced way\n\n
","active":false,"disabled":false}],// required,
                        propPaneId: 'paneId', // optional - pass in default value for demo purposes
                        propTitle: 'title', // optional - pass in default value for demo purposes
                        propActive: 'active', // optional - pass in default value for demo purposes
                        propDisabled: 'disabled', // optional - pass in default value for demo purposes
                        propContent: 'content', // optional - pass in default value for demo purposes
                        tabMode : tabM,
                        scrollToTabEdge: false, // optional - pass in default value for demo purposes
                        disableScrollArrowsOnFullyScrolled: false // optional- pass in default value for demo purposes
                    }).on('ready.scrtabs', function() {
                        $('#'+this.id+' .tab-pane').attr('tabindex',0);
                    });
                };

                activate();
            }
        }
    });
